column1:
Japanbuilder,"2016-12-28T05:21:52.857Z","Imperial flags reign!","

The Empire sends out its spies and enforcers to secure its will all over the galaxy. Are these troopers up to the task? Let'
The front and back covers depict our troopers in action in some world controlled by the Empire. Their walker is being used as support in their assault and it is very attractive overall.
The parts are the usual fare for a battle pack lots of stud blasters and fairly common parts but in grey and dark bluish grey. You will have lots of 1x1 pieces left over when finished.

As with all battlepacks this one is desired for the figures and boy do they deliver the goods! The new Death Troopers are excellently represented here with very detailed printing and their helmets are great piece of molding! They look great!

The regular stormtroopers are identical to the one found in the 2016 Star Wars Advent Calendar. Though they differ in color slightly from the ones found in the Galactic Empire Battlepack released early in 2016. Those troopers are a bit more white while these are a bit more cream white.
There are no double faces on any of them and they are sporting the standard angry clone trooper face.
The figure in the middle is the trooper from the advent calendar. The trooper on the far left is the one with the scarring from early in 2016 and our latest trooper is on the right.

The build was simple but it is for sure meant to be purchased with its counterpart set for the rebels. The walker looks awkward to me but slightly better than the small Microfighters AT-DP. Overall not bad but the figures are the draw here the build is just bonus but still fun. I like the cannons on the side of it.
I love this pack. If you are looking for troopers then this is the pack for you. The Deathtroopers fit in just fine with their brothers and certainly enhance the imperial presence wherever they are.
For play it is not very good as a stand-alone set. It feels like you may be force to getting
column2: an opposing set with this set or sometime later if you don&#39
column3: t have any rebels in your collection.&nbsp

column1: Not a bad entry in the line despite it is short play value.
If you have some spare blasters and some black technic joints you can make some cool alterations to this set to make the troopers
column2: seem more like they do in the movies. Additionally if you have an AT-DP driver or any other imperial driver you can use it to free up one of your troopers in the pack for battle.&nbsp

column1: May the force be with the rebels as you assault their positions with these fine troopers!

column2: of this set are incredible. Lego has gotten very, very good at what they do, and the printing, particularly on the death troopers, is both accurate and beautiful. The Death Trooper helmets are a new design, and are very cool. The Stormtroopers&nbsp
column3: look better than ever before, but the fact that they have changed the design again (if ever so slightly) may annoy some people.

column1: When I saw the image of the build on the box I was frankly not excited. It looked weird and not at all like anything in the Empire'
column2: s unique style. After i built it, however, I was pleasantly surprised, particularly&nbsp
column4: the walkers look very good next to each other, as if on patrol.

column1: This is a must have for any fan of Star Wars, in particular. Rogue One, if only for the absolutely stunning minifigures, which, lets be honest, is the only reason why anyone buys battlepacks in the first place.
,TRUE,5,5,2,5,5 Odeinoichus","2018-07-15T21:21:11.613Z","Rogue One Battle Pack Excellently Delivers.","
column13: > This is the 2017 Rogue One Battle Pack and it&rsquo
column14: s a great set for one reason, Death Troopers, these things were only available in a large and expensive set before now and so this having been created is a great plus for LEGO because the Death Troopers are one of the best elements Rogue One gave us.

column8: >Box: The box includes another semi-decent action shot of the set, its imagery is a little unusual actually considering the front shows the Stormtrooper piloting the mini-walker right next to the large Death Trooper helmet that was the basis of the sets from this year. I say odd mostly because it looks like the Death Trooper is actually playing with his LEGO counterparts. Which is kind of fun to think about, Star Wars characters playing with LEGO, how much fun would that be to see?
>Instructions: Compared to the previous battle pack this manual actually includes the wave set and Minifigure checklist in the back, which is a nice change of pace. There really isn&rsquo
column9: t that much else to say, it does its job properly of showing what parts to use when and the step-by-step builds are fairly easy to follow along with.

column8: >Death Trooper: Much like Shadow Troopers these figures are all in black, and they have an impressive printing detail with their armour looking quite nicely. The newly sculpted helmet captures the look of the Death Trooper perfectly in LEGO form. Unfortunately they use stud shooters for blasters, and a real big unfortunate is they have the exact same Angry Clone face Jangbricks is so fond of. (Ok, well, he isn&rsquo
column9: t, but you get my point.)

t changed much, they incorporate new printing techniques every so often, however in the end they rarely change much and so often look the same. The two in this set are no exception, they have the exact same printing and the stud launchers.

s a small one-person walker, these often share similar designs, that being said this little walker is a decent offering and the build was actually quite fun. I enjoyed creating it and playing with it means you can launch studs at the Rebels constantly. If you went so far you could take this model&rsquo
column10: s design and modify it into a Ed209 model from Robocop.

column8: >A decent enough Battle Pack and one I strongly recommend because it is the cheapest method of getting Death Troopers. The model is fun looking and more Stormtroopers is rarely a bad thing when you want an Imperial army to fight against your Rebel scum.

There are already a number of good reviews, but I have
column2: to mention how well this guy walks and stands in different poses. &nbsp

I also note that at the back of

column1:
,TRUE,5,4,4,5,3 FowlerBricks","2018-02-01T01:40:34.03Z","Death Troopers: Yes! Stormtroopers: Yes! Funky Walker: Err...","

With the semi-recent release of Rogue One, Lego has put out an array of sets based on the movie. There were two Battle Packs amongst them and today you will witness the power of the Dark Side in my review of the Imperial Troopers Battle Pack&hellip
column2: or will you? Does this set truly display the might of the Empire or not? Read on and you will see.

column1: Before I get into the actual review, I&rsquo
column2: d like to give a little history of the Battle Packs. The first ones were 7655&nbsp
column3: Clone Trooper Battle Pack (not to be confused with the Clone Troopers Battle Pack) and&nbsp
column5: Droids Battle Pack. These came out in 2007. The next wave came the next year and battle packs have continued to be released up to this year, giving us many ways to build decent armies for fairly cheap. There were a few thrown in the mix that had two heroes and two villains but these didn&#39
column7: seem to be as popular, making them disappear quickly. I can see why. Having two good guys and two bad guys makes it hard to build an army because you have to buy twice as many sets. Now, onward!

column1: The box uses the same design as the other Rogue One sets, displaying a Death Trooper against a ragged denim looking background in the top right corner and the Imperials and their walker front and center charging into battle on what appears to be Jedha.
The back of the box shows a different angle of the set plus the few play features. It also appears that the Troopers are no longer on Jedha.
The Instructions are standard Lego fare with the same design as the box.
In the back of the Instructions there is a neat little set/minifigure display along with an advertisement for the Force Builder app.
This is obviously the main draw of the set. The Minifigures are what makes a Battle Pack&hellip
column2: or breaks it. Fortunately this set has a pretty solid offering. Two Death Troopers plus two Stormtroopers. The Death Troopers are slightly different from the ones included in Krennic&rsquo
column3: s shuttle. The helmets, legs and heads are the same but the pauldron is absent and the torso print is different, making these normal Death Troopers (if you can call Death Troopers normal) instead of specialists.

column1: This is a nice change since it makes army building easier (the whole point of the set). These are excellent minifigures. The helmet is accurately molded with dark bluish gray detail and two tiny splashes of green plus some shiny silver vents on the vocoder. The silver and gray detail continues on the torso (front and back) and down to the legs.
And yes, the heads are just angry clone again but you&rsquo
column2: re supposed to keep the helmet on, so I won&rsquo
column3: t complain. All the prints on the body and legs are clean and crisp, but I noticed the lines on one of my Death Trooper&rsquo
column5: thicker and slightly smudged. It is&nbsp
column6: easily overlooked, though and I am quite satisfied with them. Both Death Troopers come equipped with stud shooters. This is not a movie accurate gun, though it does add some play value. A more accurate blaster can be built with a standard long blaster rifle and a Black Technic peg, if you wish.

column1: Next we have the two Stormtroopers. They&rsquo
column2: re nothing special, just the current Stormtrooper design (which I am a huge fan of, by the way), but hey, you can never have too many Stormtroopers right?&nbsp
column3: They also come with stud blasters.

column1: Nothing too eye-catching. five smooth slopes (Plate W. Bow 2x2x2/3) in light grey plus some stud shooters and a smattering of dark tan 1x2 plates.
A nice mix of simple stacking and a tiny bit of SNOT. Easy to understand, so even younger kids could probably build it pretty quickly.

column2: t know what to think about this walker. There are some aspects of it that I really like: the elevating guns, the design of the body, the color scheme, the spot to store the pilot&rsquo
column3: s blaster and the legs have a fairly wide range of movement.

column1: There are also some aspects that I really don&rsquo
column2: t like: the pilot sits up way too high. The windscreen is useless.

column1: Any sniper worth his Tibanna gas could take out the pilot without even breaking a sweat.
The legs of the walker are rather skinny and void of detail and the feet are too small, making it near impossible
column2: to pose the walker without it falling over.

column1: There are also some strange gaps in the front that could have easily been blocked up by adding two more 1x2 plates.
It does look better in real life than it does on the box, though. It looks horrible on the box, so don&rsquo
column2: t judge it by that picture. I don&rsquo
column3: t recall seeing any walkers like this in Rogue One, but maybe it&rsquo
column4: s a Battlefront thing or maybe Lego just made it up for the set. Either way, you have to form your own opinion. Kids will probably love it and not care how it looks, just that it shoots. AFOL&rsquo

column1: On the whole, this set is excellent, but that&rsquo
column3: s a cheap way to obtain some Death Troopers and extra Stormtroopers. The Walker&rsquo
column4: s guns certainly look intimidating, but if I were a Rebel, I&rsquo
column5: d just laugh and shoot the Stormtrooper off the top of the thing. $15 seems slightly pricey, not too bad but you may want to wait for a sale anyhow. I definitely recommend that you pick up a few, but&hellip
column7: t judge you if you never build the walker. So maybe this set doesn&#39
column8: t display the full might of the Empire, but it does pretty well despite some large flaws.

column1:
,TRUE,5,3,3,4,3 Clone_Commander_stone","2017-03-18T18:29:42.82Z","A great way to get some Death Troopers ","

This set is a great way to get some Death troopers and is the main reason I bought the set. I was not interested in krennics
column2: shuttle when it was released , as I had had Kylo&nbsp
column3: Rens shuttle the year before, so I just knew I had to have the set to get the Death troopers.

column2: t much, it represents an imperial walker of some kind. It uses some quite good pieces that would be good for Mocs.&nbsp

column1: The minifigures are the main reason to buy the set. The set includes four figures: two new versions of stormtroopers(which were first released in 2014) and two new death troopers which are exclusive to this set. The Death troopers are different to the ones in Krennics
column2: shuttle as they are trooper versions not commander versions in this set.the Death troopers are also good to build an army&nbsp
column3: The stormtroopers are also good figures to build an army.&nbsp

column1: Overall I think this set is very good for the price of £
column2: 11.99 as it has four figures and a imperial walker. This set is also better than buying four The Lego batman movie minifigures because you get an imperial walker as well. The only thing that could make the set better is if it had an &nbsp
column3: imperial officer instead of one of the generic stormtroopers.&nbsp

column1:
,TRUE,5,4,4,5,5 cobracat519","2018-07-19T16:42:55.37Z","75165-1: Imperial Trooper Battle Pack - Perfect army builder!","

This is the ideal battle pack. Who doesn'
column2: t want plain Stormtroopers? Plus Deathtroopers? I mean, you can get a bunch of these and build up a decent army of Stormtroopers and Deathtroopers. The walker is kind of cool, but is just a build to fill out the price point. The pieces used are good, and usable elsewhere. The only real downside to the set is the studshooters. But that just goes for collectors. The Deathtroopers are also unique in the set, which is yet another plus. This is a really good set.

column1:
,TRUE,5,4,3,4,5 alfred_the_buttler","2018-08-10T04:46:20.5Z","Fantastic value and great playability ","

I got this set for my 4 year old son because he really wanted it. I knew that it would be difficult for him to build, but it cost $12 and had 4 minifigures plus he loves AT-ST&rsquo
column2: s. Well he definitely cannot build it, way too difficult, but he absolutely loves to play with it and can usually repair it when something breaks off.&nbsp

come with blasters that can actually fire, and there are 2 more on the AT-ST which make the set a ton of fun. The AT-ST can stand very well, although it is sometimes difficult for my son to stand it on his own.&nbsp

column1: One day my son will be able to build this, but for now the storm troopers spend most of their time destroying police cars, which my son can easily rebuild.

Its not a huge set, but it is a tremendous value and a lot of fun to play with. When combined with other Star Wars sets, it really gives you a very good sized imperial army. Easily the best Star Wars set for pre-schoolers.

,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 lego_collector_123","2020-02-23T02:12:20.653Z","Awesome Troopers! ","

Lego often releases nice battlepacks and this one looks to have some great figures.
Death troopers x2: I love the Death trooper design in the movie Rogue One, and I'
column2: m glad to get two of these figures in an inexpensive set. The unique helmet mould looks ok although I feel it juts out a bit too far. The print on the helmet is great however. Both minifigures have the angry clone face print
column3: I would rather they each had different expressions. The torso and legs have fantastic prints. Each trooper carries a stud shooter which is good for play although I&#39
column4: d prefer they had realistic blasters.

column1: Stormtroopers x2: I like getting standard troopers in battlepacks. The Stormtrooper'
column2: s helmets look perfect including both the print and the mould. Sadly, these troopers also have angry clone faces. The simple torso prints show the appropriate armour and the legs have a great print with lots of detail. They also carry stud shooters.

column1: Lego Star Wars battlepacks often include actual Star Wars vehicles but in this case a custom walker was created. The body of the walker is designed to fit a single pilot. I like the inclusion of a small clip on the back to store the troopers weapon while he rides the walker. Two canons on the sides can be angled 360 degrees and feature stud shooters. The legs have three points of articulation and can pose fairly well. I personally dislike the look of the walker, and would have preferred an actual Star Wars vehicle.

The minifigures are the highlight of all battlepacks and all four figures look fantastic. Despite the fact I dislike the main build, it still plays well. $23 aud is the standard price for a battlepack and I definitely recommend this set.&nbsp

column2: I did not get this set the year it was released. I got the set for Christmas one year after it had been discontinued during the Covid lock down.&nbsp

The Minifigures in this set are perfect for army building. To start off with you have two Death Troopers. The helmet is a special mould with gay printing and green accents on the breathing filters. Their torsos are printed with grey accents as well as their legs. Their armed with stud shooters.

There is also included two pre2019 stormtroopers. Their helmets are printed with black markings and blue and grey highlights. Their torsos and legs have armour printing on them. They are also armed with stud shooters.

The build in this set is a LEGO made up Walker entirely for this set. It has moving legs and several adjustable turrets on the side. The pilot is exposed and there is a clip for the troopers stud shooter.&nbsp

Overall the Minifigures are definitely the highlight of this set. The Walker is arguably one of the weakest LEGO models in an official set I have ever seen. I would definitely recommend this set,&nbsp
column3: if you could even find it for a decent price.
